New Records: Shohei Ohtani became the first major league player with at least 50 home runs and 50 stolen bases in a season.
Ohtani became the first big league player to hit three homers and steal two bases in a game.
Ohtani broke the Dodgers’ franchise record of 49 homers set by Shawn Green in 2001.
Ohtani became the third player in major league history with at least six hits, three homers, and 10 RBIs in a game.
Key Match Events: Shohei Ohtani hit his 49th homer in the sixth inning, his 50th in the seventh, and his 51st in the ninth.
Ohtani stole his 50th base in the first inning and his 51st in the second.
Ohtani's performance secured a playoff spot for the Dodgers.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers shortstop Miguel Rojas expressed a lot of emotions because of everything that happens behind the scenes.
Ohtani said he wanted to get over the milestone as quickly as possible and will cherish it for a very long time.
Marlins manager Skip Schumaker decided against intentionally walking Ohtani out of respect for the game.
Catcher Will Smith noted Ohtani's hard work and preparation.
Manager Dave Roberts mentioned that Ohtani is emptying the tank offensively this year as he is not pitching.
Outfielder Tommy Edman and third baseman Max Muncy praised Ohtani's consistent and remarkable performances.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Ohtani signed a $700 million, 10-year deal with the Dodgers last December.
Ohtani has been playing exclusively as a designated hitter this season while rehabilitating from elbow surgery.
Ohtani's performance at LoanDepot Park was another memorable moment, where he previously struck out Mike Trout in the 2023 World Baseball Classic championship.
